      • RESERVED_20_20
        Description:
        • reserved_20_20
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_RESERVED_20_21

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x21
  • Summary: Reserved.
  • Purpose:
    • Reserved.
  • Defaults: 0x00
  • Register View:
    MODEM_RESERVED_20_21
    Index76543210
    0x21 RESERVED_20_21
    Defaults
    0x21 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_RESERVED_20_21
      • RESERVED_20_21
        Description:
        • reserved_20_21
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_BCR_OSR

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x22 ... 0x23
  • Summary: RX BCR/Slicer oversampling rate (12-bit unsigned number).
  • Purpose:
    • The RX Modem in the chip contains a Numerically Controlled Oscillator (NCO) for the purpose of synchronizing a local bit clock to the received data stream. The timing of this NCO is maintained by a feedback loop called the Bit Clock Recovery (BCR) loop.
    • The BCR loop is sampled at a rate higher than the RX data rate. The ratio between the sampling rate and the RX data rate is called the BCR oversampling rate (OSR), with typical values of OSR = 8 to 12. The desired value of OSR is calculated as a function of the channel filter bandwidth and RX data rate, and reflects a compromise between low clock jitter (high sample rate) and lower current consumption and improved adjacent channel filter attenuation (low sample rate).
    • The BCR loop sampling clock is derived from the crystal oscillator through a series of decimations, and thus the sampling rate is controlled by the NDEC2, NDEC1, NDEC0, DWN3BYP, and DWN2BYP bits in the MODEM_DECIMATION_CFG properties. In (G)FSK mode, the channel filter and BCR loop use the same sampling clock rate; in OOK mode, the BCR loop uses a lower sampling clock rate by additionally configuring the NDEC0 parameter.
    • The 12-bit value programmed into the MODEM_BCR_OSR properties represents the target value of OSR multiplied by 8x (alternatively, the 12-bit value may be viewed as a 9-bit integer portion and 3-bit fractional portion). Example: for a target value of OSR = 11.75, the value of MODEM_BCR_OSR = 0x5E.
    • This property defines the RX BCR/Slicer oversampling rate.
  • Defaults: 0x00, 0x4b
  • Register View:
    MODEM_BCR_OSR
    Index76543210
    0x22 0 0 0 0 RXOSR[11:8]
    0x23 RXOSR[7:0]
    Defaults
    0x22 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0
    0x23 0x4b

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_BCR_OSR
      • RXOSR
        Description:
        • RX symbol oversampling rate at the BCR/Slicer.
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_BCR_NCO_OFFSET

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x24 ... 0x26
  • Summary: RX BCR NCO offset value (an unsigned 22-bit number).
  • Purpose:
    • The RX Modem in the chip contains a Numerically Controlled Oscillator (NCO) for the purpose of synchronizing a local bit clock to the received data stream. The timing of this NCO is maintained by a feedback loop called the Bit Clock Recovery (BCR) loop.
    • The NCO operates by accumulating a programmed offset value on each tick of the BCR oversampling clock signal (see MODEM_BCR_OSR for more details of the BCR/Slicer oversampling clock). The rate at which the accumulator overflows is therefore a function of the word-width of the accumulator, the programmed offset value, and the BCR oversampling clock rate.
    • The NCO accumulator generates a pulse each time it overflows; the programmed offset value is selected such that the rate of pulses produced by the accumulator equals the desired RX data rate.
    • The 22-bit value programmed into the MODEM_BCR_NCO_OFFSET property represents the target offset value multiplied by 64x (alternatively, the 22-bit value may be viewed as a 16-bit integer portion and 6-bit fractional portion). Example: for a target offset value of OFFSET = 5592.40625, the value of MODEM_BCR_NCO_OFFSET = 0x05761A.
  • Defaults: 0x06, 0xd3, 0xa0
  • Register View:
    MODEM_BCR_NCO_OFFSET
    Index76543210
    0x24 0 0 NCOFF[21:16]
    0x25 NCOFF[15:8]
    0x26 NCOFF[7:0]
    Defaults
    0x24 0x0 0x0 0x6
    0x25 0xd3
    0x26 0xa0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_BCR_NCO_OFFSET
      • NCOFF
        Description:
        • The RX BCR NCO offset value.
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_BCR_GAIN

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x27 ... 0x28
  • Summary: The unsigned 11-bit RX BCR loop gain value.
  • Purpose:
    • The RX Modem in the chip contains a Numerically Controlled Oscillator (NCO) for the purpose of synchronizing a local bit clock to the received data stream. The timing of this NCO is maintained by a feedback loop called the Bit Clock Recovery (BCR) loop. (Please refer to the text description for MODEM_BCR_NCO_OFFSET for more details regarding the BCR NCO.)
    • The BCR NCO provides a local clock signal that is at the desired data rate; however, a method of synchronizing the phase of the local clock signal to that of the received data stream is also required. This phase alignment is accomplished by measuring the phase difference between the local bit clock and the received data stream, and adjusting the phase of the bit clock by means of a feedback loop.
    • This property adjusts the gain of the BCR feedback loop. A large value of gain results in fast acquisition of timing but increased clock jitter, while a low value of gain provides lower clock jitter but slower timing acquisition.
    • The chip provides for switching the loop gain (i.e., "gear shifting") at a configurable point during the packet. This allows the chip to initially use a high loop gain value (resulting in fast acquisition of timing during reception of the Preamble), followed by a lower loop gain value (resulting in low clock jitter during reception of the Payload).
    • The clock recovery gain in MODEM_BCR_GAIN is an unsigned 11-bit value that serves as a common "baseline" gain value; it is further scaled by individually selectable scale factors to determine the effective loop gain values to be used prior to and after gear shifting. These scale factors are specified by MODEM_BCR_GEAR:CRFAST and MODEM_BCR_GEAR:CRSLOW .
  • Defaults: 0x06, 0xd3
  • Register View:
    MODEM_BCR_GAIN
    Index76543210
    0x27 0 0 0 0 0 CRGAIN[10:8]
    0x28 CRGAIN[7:0]
    Defaults
    0x27 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x6
    0x28 0xd3

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_BCR_GAIN
      • CRGAIN
        Description:
        • The clock recovery timing loop gain.
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_BCR_GEAR

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x29
  • Summary: RX BCR loop gear control.
  • Purpose:
    • RX BCR loop gear control.
    • A reduced value of bit clock recovery gain is often desired after gear shifting (to reduce clock jitter). The BCR loop gain in both gear modes is obtained from a baseline clock recovery gain value (crgain in the MODEM_BCR_GAIN_x properties), scaled by the crfast and crslow values specified in this property. NOTE: larger values of crfast or crslow result in lower values of bit clock recovery gain.
  • Defaults: 0x02
  • Register View:
    MODEM_BCR_GEAR
    Index76543210
    0x29 0 0 CRFAST CRSLOW
    Defaults
    0x29 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x2

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_BCR_GEAR
      • CRFAST
        Description:
        • The fast timing gain applies before gear switching occurs. The effective BCR loop gain is calculated as: crgain/(2^crfast).
        Type:
        U8
      • CRSLOW
        Description:
        • The slow timing gain applies after gear switching occurs. The effective BCR loop gain is calculated as: crgain/(2^crslow).
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_BCR_MISC1

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x2a
  • Summary: Miscellaneous control bits for the RX BCR loop.
  • Purpose:
    • This property configures miscellaneous options within the RX BCR loop.
  • Defaults: 0xc0
  • Register View:
    MODEM_BCR_MISC1
    Index76543210
    0x2a BCRFBBYP SLICEFBBYP 0 RXNCOCOMP RXCOMP_LAT CRGAINX2 DIS_MIDPT ESC_MIDPT
    Defaults
    0x2a 0x1 0x1 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_BCR_MISC1
      • BCRFBBYP
        Description:
        • The frequency of the down-converted signal in the IF may not be perfectly centered in the IF (e.g. PLL-based AFC correction is disabled or settles with some small residual frequency error).
        • If left uncompensated, this residual frequency error may degrade the ability of the BCR and Slicer to track and slice the data bits (respectively).
        • In normal operation, the measured residual frequency error is provided as feedback to the BCR and Slicer to compensate their performance.
        • This bit disables the feedback term to the BCR tracking loop. This is normally used only for diagnostics purposes or during reception of special test signals (e.g., BER tests).
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENABLED0
        • Feedback of the compensation term to the BCR tracking loop is enabled (normal operation).
        DISABLED1
        • Feedback of the compensation term to the BCR tracking loop is bypassed (disabled).
      • SLICEFBBYP
        Description:
        • Please refer to the text description for MODEM_BCR_MISC1:BCRFBBYP for further details regarding this functionality.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENABLED0
        • Feedback of the compensation term to the slicer is enabled (normal operation).
        DISABLED1
        • Feedback of the compensation term to the slicer is bypassed (disabled).
      • RXNCOCOMP
        Description:
        • The RX Modem in the chip contains a Numerically Controlled Oscillator (NCO) for the purpose of synchronizing a local bit clock to the received data stream. (Please refer to the text description for MODEM_BCR_NCO_OFFSET for more details regarding the BCR NCO.)
        • The free-running frequency of the NCO is normally set to a fixed value (appropriate for the selected data rate) and used throughout the entire packet.
        • In the event of receiving a packet with a large error in the data rate, the BCR loop may not be able to maintain tracking without first obtaining a more accurate estimate of the actual received data rate.
        • This bit allows the chip to compensate for data rate error by acquiring a new estimate for the NCO frequency from the received data itself. This new NCO frequency estimate is obtained during the Preamble field, and then used for the remainder of the packet.
        • This compensation is typically needed only when the data rate error is greater than 1%.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DISABLED0
        • Compensation of the BCR NCO frequency is disabled (normal operation).
        ENABLED1
        • Compensation of the BCR NCO frequency is enabled.
      • RXCOMP_LAT
        Description:
        • This bit determines the location in the packet at which the new estimation of BCR NCO frequency is taken.
        • This bit has no effect if RXNCOCOMP is not also set; please refer to the text description for RXNCOCOMP for further details.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        SAMP_PREAMBLE_END0
        • BCR NCO compensation is sampled upon detection of the end of the Preamble (i.e., boundary between Preamble and Sync Word).
        SAMP_PREAMBLE_VALID1
        • BCR NCO compensation is sampled upon detection of PREAMBLE_VALID.
      • CRGAINX2
        Description:
        • Selects whether the BCR loop gain will be increased by a factor of 2x.
        • This gain increase applies to all modes of operation (i.e., both high-gear and low-gear modes).
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        NORMAL0
        • BCR loop gain is not doubled (normal operation).
        DOUBLED1
        • BCR loop gain is doubled.
      • DIS_MIDPT
        Description:
        • The BCR loop attempts to synchronize the local RX bit clock to the edge transitions of the received data bits by sampling the phase at 1*Tb intervals.
        • The sensitivity of the phase sampling process may be reduced if the BCR loop accidentally aligns to sampling at the mid-point of the data bits instead of at bit boundaries. In extreme conditions, the sampled phase information may not be sufficient to drive the BCR loop away from the mid-point condition and towards the optimal bit boundary sampling condition.
        • This mid-point sampling condition may be detected and corrected by deliberately "kicking" the BCR loop slightly.
        • This functionality only applies to demodulation of a 2(G)FSK signal with a standard '1010...' Preamble pattern using the Synchronous Demodulator.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENABLED0
        • Correction of a BCR mid-point phase sampling condition by resetting the NCO is enabled (normal operation).
        DISABLED1
        • Correction of a BCR mid-point phase sampling condition by resetting the NCO is disabled.
      • ESC_MIDPT
        Description:
        • Selects the method of "kicking" the BCR loop to escape a mid-point phase sampling condition, as described for the DIS_MIDPT bit.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ESCAPE_1CLK0
        • Upon detection of a BCR mid-point phase sampling condition, the NCO will stop running for one sample clock to escape.
        ESCAPE_PHASE_ERR1
        • Upon detection of a BCR mid-point phase sampling condition, the current phase error is added to the NCO to escape.

MODEM_BCR_MISC0

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x2b
  • Summary: Miscellaneous RX BCR loop controls.
  • Purpose:
    • This property configures miscellaneous options within the RX BCR loop.
  • Defaults: 0x00
  • Register View:
    MODEM_BCR_MISC0
    Index76543210
    0x2b ADCWATCH ADCRST DISTOGG PH0SIZE RES_LOCKUP_BYP 0 0 DSA_BCR_RST
    Defaults
    0x2b 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_BCR_MISC0
      • ADCWATCH
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • ADC watch dog is disabled.
        ENUM_11
        • ADC watch dog is enabled. If the invalid preamble is detected and no 1010 pattern is detected, ADC reset will be generated.
      • ADCRST
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • ADC watch dog is disabled.
        ENUM_11
        • Enable ADC reset from AGC loop. If IF-PD's current and previous high threshold exceed, ADC reset will be generated.
      • DISTOGG
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • Normal.
        ENUM_11
        • Enabled. If the phase differential output is zero, the discriminator output will be toggling.
      • PH0SIZE
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • 5 consecutive zeros of phase differential output will cause RX machine reset.
        ENUM_11
        • 3 consecutive zeros of phase differential output will cause RX machine reset.
      • RES_LOCKUP_BYP
        Description:
        • Needs to be set during BER testing.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DISABLED0
        • Disable lockup detector.
        ENABLED1
        • Enable lockup detector.
      • DSA_BCR_RST
        Description:
        • Needs to be set if signal arrival is enabled for BCR loop's NCO reset during BER testing.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DISABLED0
        • Disable BCR reset from phase difference zero checking block.
        ENABLED1
        • Enable BCR reset from phase difference zero checking block.

MODEM_AFC_GEAR

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x2c
  • Summary: RX AFC loop gear control.
  • Purpose:
    • Selection of gear switching source for both RX AFC and BCR.
    • Control of gain for RX AFC in both FAST and SLOW modes (i.e., before and after gear switching)
  • Defaults: 0x00
  • Register View:
    MODEM_AFC_GEAR
    Index76543210
    0x2c GEAR_SW AFC_FAST AFC_SLOW
    Defaults
    0x2c 0x0 0x0 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_AFC_GEAR
      • GEAR_SW
        Description:
        • Selects the event upon which gear switching will occur. Gear switching simultaneously affects the BCR tracking loop as well as the PLL-based AFC loop (if enabled).
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • Preamble detection - switch gears after detection of Preamble.
        ENUM_11
        • Sync word detection - switch gears after detection of Sync Word.
        ENUM_22
        • Mid-Point frequency error detection - switch gears when the estimated frequency error of the Min-Max detector in the Asynchronous Demodulator is less than the half eye-threshold for a consecutive number of search periods. NOTE: The consecutive number of search periods is defined MODEM_RAW_SEARCH:SCH_FRZTH , while the length of each search period (in bits) is defined by MODEM_RAW_SEARCH:SCHPRD_HI .
        ENUM_33
        • Preamble detection - switch gears after detection of Preamble (same as gear_sw = 0)
      • AFC_FAST
        Description:
        • Sets the gain of the PLL-based AFC acquisition loop prior to gear switching (i.e., during Fast tracking mode).
        • The gain of the AFC loop is the product of a baseline gain value and a scale factor that differs according to gear switching. The baseline gain value is specified by MODEM_AFC_GAIN while the scale factors are held by the AFC_FAST and AFC_SLOW parameters.
        • The gain of the AFC loop in Fast tracking mode is MODEM_AFC_GAIN * 2-AFC_FAST, and thus a larger value of AFC_FAST results in slower AFC tracking speed prior to gear switching.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0x7
      • AFC_SLOW
        Description:
        • Sets the gain of the PLL-based AFC acquisition loop after gear switching (i.e., during Slow tracking mode).
        • The gain of the AFC loop is the product of a baseline gain value and a scale factor that differs according to gear switching. The baseline gain value is specified by MODEM_AFC_GAIN while the scale factors are held by the AFC_FAST and AFC_SLOW parameters.
        • The gain of the AFC loop in Slow tracking mode is MODEM_AFC_GAIN * 2-AFC_SLOW, and thus a larger value of AFC_SLOW results in slower AFC tracking speed after gear switching.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0x7

MODEM_AFC_WAIT

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x2d
  • Summary: RX AFC loop wait time control.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip provides for Automatic Frequency Correction (AFC) in RX mode to improve reception of the signal in the presence of frequency error in the link. The frequency error is measured and corrected during the initial acquisition of the packet (e.g., during the Preamble), allowing optimized reception of the remainder of the packet.
    • One form of AFC provided by the chip operates by adjusting the frequency of the RX LO signal from the PLL Synthesizer, and strives to position the down-converted IF signal in the center of the IF passband. This PLL-based form of AFC thus operates in the analog domain; the chip also provides for other forms of AFC that operate in the digital domain of the RX Modem. The SHWAIT and LGWAIT parameters in the MODEM_AFC_WAIT property affect only PLL-based AFC.
    • Each AFC correction cycle consists of: a) measuring the frequency error, b) adjusting the frequency of the PLL, and c) allowing the PLL to settle prior to taking another measurement of frequency error.
    • The SHWAIT and LGWAIT parameters determine the periods of time allowed for the PLL to settle after each AFC adjustment cycle. Two different waiting periods (short and long) are provided, depending upon whether the AFC algorithm is operating before or after gear switching.
    • The waiting time is in multiples of the symbol period, and thus changes as a function of the data rate. At higher data rates (i.e., shorter symbol periods), the values of the SHWAIT and LGWAIT parameters may need to be increased to provide sufficient time for the PLL to re-settle after correction. The WDS Calculator automatically suggests appropriate values as a function of the selected data rate.
  • Defaults: 0x23
  • Register View:
    MODEM_AFC_WAIT
    Index76543210
    0x2d SHWAIT LGWAIT
    Defaults
    0x2d 0x2 0x3

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_AFC_WAIT
      • SHWAIT
        Description:
        • This specifies the wait period per PLL AFC correction cycle before gear switching has occurred. The SHWAIT parameter is typically set to a value smaller than the LGWAIT parameter, as fast acquisition speed prior to gear switching is usually desirable.
        • The effective wait time is (SHWAIT+1)*2Tb.
        • When set to '0' then no PLL AFC correction will occur before gear switching, i.e., PLL AFC is disabled before gear switching.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0xf
      • LGWAIT
        Description:
        • This specifies the wait period per PLL AFC correction cycle after gear switching has occurred. The LGWAIT parameter is typically set to a value larger than the SHWAIT parameter, as robust tracking of unbalanced data after gear switching is usually desirable.
        • The effective wait time is (LGWAIT+1)*2Tb.
        • When set to '0' then no PLL AFC correction will occur after gear switching, i.e., PLL AFC is disabled after gear switching.
        • If MODEM_AFC_MISC:ENAFCFRZ is set, there will be no PLL AFC correction after gear switching, regardless of the value of LGWAIT.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0xf

MODEM_AFC_GAIN

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x2e ... 0x2f
  • Summary: Sets the gain of the PLL-based AFC acquisition loop, and provides miscellaneous control bits for AFC functionality.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip provides for Automatic Frequency Correction (AFC) functionality in which the frequency error of the received signal is measured and used to adjust the PLL Synthesizer to position the down-converted IF signal in the center of the IF bandwidth.
    • The AFC algorithm uses a feedback loop to track the frequency of the incoming signal. The gain of the AFC loop is the product of a baseline gain value and a scale factor that differs according to gear switching. The baseline gain value is specified by this property (an unsigned 13-bit value) while the scale factors are held by the MODEM_AFC_GEAR:AFC_FAST and MODEM_AFC_GEAR:AFC_SLOW parameters.
    • The ENAFC parameter enables the frequency error estimation circuitry.
    • The AFCBD parameter enables dynamic switching of the RX bandwidth during the packet. Please refer to MODEM_CHFLT_RX2_CHFLT_COE for further details regarding the use of adaptive RX bandwidth.
  • Defaults: 0x83, 0x69
  • Register View:
    MODEM_AFC_GAIN
    Index76543210
    0x2e ENAFC AFCBD AFC_GAIN_DIV AFCGAIN[12:8]
    0x2f AFCGAIN[7:0]
    Defaults
    0x2e 0x1 0x0 0x0 0x3
    0x2f 0x69

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_AFC_GAIN
      • ENAFC
        Description:
        • When set, enables estimation of the frequency error.
        • Estimated frequency error is made available to feedback to the Frac-N PLL, BCR and Slicer. NOTE: enabling of each individual AFC function is performed in the MODEM_BCR_MISC1 and MODEM_AFC_MISC properties.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DISABLE0
        • Estimation of frequency error is disabled. This effectively disables all forms of AFC (both PLL-based AFC as well as Slicer and BCR compensation).
        ENABLE1
        • Estimation of frequency error is enabled.
      • AFCBD
        Description:
        • If set, enables the use of adaptive RX bandwidth across the packet.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DISABLE0
        • Adaptive RX bandwidth is disabled. The RX channel filter coefficients specified in MODEM_CHFLT_RX1_CHFLT_COE are used across the entire packet.
        ENABLE1
        • Adaptive RX bandwidth is enabled. The RX channel filter coefficients specified in MODEM_CHFLT_RX1_CHFLT_COE are used prior to gear switching, and the coefficients specified in MODEM_CHFLT_RX2_CHFLT_COE are used after gear switching.
      • AFC_GAIN_DIV
        Description:
        • Reduces AFC loop gain by half when set.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        NO_REDUCTION0
        • AFC loop gain is not reduced (normal operation).
        REDUCTION_BY_HALF1
        • AFC loop gain is reduced by half.
      • AFCGAIN
        Description:
        • 13-bit AFC loop gain value.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0x1fff

MODEM_AFC_LIMITER

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x30 ... 0x31
  • Summary: Set the AFC limiter value.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip provides for Automatic Frequency Correction (AFC) functionality in which the frequency error of the received signal is measured and used to adjust the PLL Synthesizer to position the down-converted IF signal in the center of the IF bandwidth.
    • This property provides a "watchdog" upper limit on how far the AFC tracking loop may vary from the commanded channel center frequency (i.e., due to tracking on noise). Upon reaching this limit, the AFC algorithm is reset to begin reacquisition from the channel center frequency.
  • Defaults: 0x00, 0x40
  • Register View:
    MODEM_AFC_LIMITER
    Index76543210
    0x30 0 AFCLIM[14:8]
    0x31 AFCLIM[7:0]
    Defaults
    0x30 0x0 0x0
    0x31 0x40

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_AFC_LIMITER
      • AFCLIM
        Description:
        • 15-bit AFC limiter value. If the frequency error measured by the AFC correction algorithm exceeds this value, the AFC algorithm is reset to begin reacquisition from channel center frequency.
        • The AFC limiter value should be viewed as a 14-bit value plus an additional bit that enables an 8x scale factor. If AFCLIM[14] = '0', then the AFC limiter value is AFCLIM[13:0]. If AFCLIM[14] = '1', then the AFC limiter value is AFCLIM[13:0]*8.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0x7fff

MODEM_AFC_MISC

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x32
  • Summary: Specifies miscellaneous AFC control bits.
  • Purpose:
    • Specifies miscellaneous bits for control of AFC functionality.
  • Defaults: 0xa0
  • Register View:
    MODEM_AFC_MISC
    Index76543210
    0x32 ENAFCFRZ ENFBPLL EN2TB_EST ENFZPMEND ENAFC_CLKSW OOK_ZEROG NON_FRZEN LARGE_FREQ_ERR
    Defaults
    0x32 0x1 0x0 0x1 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_AFC_MISC
      • ENAFCFRZ
        Description:
        • Selects whether the AFC will operate over the entire packet, or will be frozen after gear switching.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        AFC_PKT0
        • AFC will operate over the entire packet.
        AFC_FRZN_AFTER_GEAR_SW1
        • AFC will be frozen after the gear switching.
      • ENFBPLL
        Description:
        • Selects whether the estimation of frequency error (i.e., AFC correction value) will be provided as feedback to adjust the PLL Synthesizer frequency.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DISABLE_AFC_COR_PLL0
        • Disable AFC correction value feedback to the PLL.
        ENABLE_AFC_COR_PLL1
        • Enable AFC correction value feedback to the PLL.
      • EN2TB_EST
        Description:
        • Selects whether AFC correction uses the estimation of frequency error developed by the Moving Average or Min-Max detector in the Asynchronous Demodulator, or the 2*Tb estimator in the Synchronous Demodulator.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        AFC_COR_MA0
        • AFC correction uses the frequency estimation developed by the Moving Average or Min-Max detector in the Asynchronous Demodulator.
        AFC_COR_2TB1
        • AFC correction uses the frequency estimation developed by the 2*Tb estimator in the Synchronous Demodulator. This bit must be set for proper reception of a standard packet using the Synchronous Demodulator.
      • ENFZPMEND
        Description:
        • Selects whether the AFC will freeze at the end of the '...10101...' Preamble pattern (i.e., boundary between Preamble and Sync Word).
        • This functionality may be useful if a very long Preamble is used and very good frequency error correction is desired. Setting the ENAFCFRZ bit will take precedence over setting this bit (i.e., the AFC may be frozen earlier, as determined by the gear switching source).
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        NO_AFC_FRZN0
        • AFC will not be frozen at the end of the Preamble.
        AFC_FRZN_PREAMBLE1
        • AFC will be frozen at the end of the Preamble.
      • ENAFC_CLKSW
        Description:
        • Selects whether the clock source for the 2*Tb frequency estimator is switched from a free-running bit clock to the BCR's bit clock upon detection of PREAMBLE_VALID.
        • This bit is most useful when used together with the ENFZPMEND bit; that is, when a long Preamble is available and very good frequency error correction is desired.
        • This bit has no effect if the EN2TB_EST bit is not also set (i.e., if the Asynchronous Demodulator is in use.)
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        NO_CLK_SW0
        • The clock source for the 2*Tb frequency estimator is not switched.
        CLK_SW_TO_BCR_BCLK1
        • The clock source for the 2*Tb frequency estimator is switched to the BCR's bit clock upon detection of PREAMBLE_VALID.
      • OOK_ZEROG
        Description:
        • The chip is capable of receiving an OOK signal while operating in zero-IF mode. (Note: this feature is currently disabled in firmware.)
        • It is important that the received OOK signal not be located precisely at zero frequency, as signals near DC are removed by filtering.
        • To guard against this, pseudo-random (G)FSK modulation is added to the RX LO, thus ensuring that the received signal is not statically positioned near DC.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        FSK_MOD0
        • FSK modulation will be added to the RX LO in OOK zero-IF mode.
        GFSK_LO_MOD1
        • GFSK LO modulation will be added to the RX LO in OOK zero-IF mode.
      • NON_FRZEN
        Description:
        • Selects whether AFC correction to the PLL is frozen.
        • This bit only has an effect for a very specific chip configuration: a) the Asynchronous Demodulator is in use, b) the modulation type is not OOK, and c) the Min-Max detector is used to develop the slicing threshold level (as configured in the MODEM_OOK_MISC property).
        • When configured in this fashion, the chip will normally freeze AFC correction to the PLL when a sufficient length of consecutive 1's or 0's is encountered, as the chip may not be able to correctly estimate the frequency error within the given search period.
        • The consecutive number of search periods is defined by MODEM_RAW_SEARCH:SCH_FRZTH , while the length of each search period is defined by MODEM_RAW_SEARCH:SCHPRD_HI .
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        AFC_FRZN_CONSEC_BITS0
        • AFC correction of the PLL will be frozen if a consecutive string of 1's or 0's that exceed the search period is encountered.
        AFC_ALWAYS_EN1
        • AFC correction of the PLL will remain enabled if a consecutive string of 1's or 0's that exceed the search period is encountered.
      • LARGE_FREQ_ERR
        Description:
        • Setting this bit expands the range of the AFC acquisition algorithm. It is recommended to set this bit when the expected frequency error is larger than 12*Symbol_Rate.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DISABLED0
        • Expected range of frequency error is normal (less than 12*Symbol_Rate)
        ENABLED1
        • Expected range of frequency error is large (greater than 12*Symbol_Rate)

MODEM_AFC_ZIFOFF

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x33
  • Summary: AFC fixed frequency offset in zero IF mode.
  • Purpose:
    • AFC fixed frequency offset in zero IF mode.
  • Defaults: 0x00
  • Register View:
    MODEM_AFC_ZIFOFF
    Index76543210
    0x33 ZEROFF
    Defaults
    0x33 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_AFC_ZIFOFF
      • ZEROFF
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_ADC_CTRL

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x34
  • Summary: Sigma Delta ADC controls.
  • Purpose:
    • This property configures various options in the sigma delta ADC.
  • Defaults: 0x00
  • Register View:
    MODEM_ADC_CTRL
    Index76543210
    0x34 0 0 0 HGAIN EN_DRST 0 REALADC 0
    Defaults
    0x34 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_ADC_CTRL
      • HGAIN
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_01
        • Adds 12 dB gain to ADC input for IR calibration.
      • EN_DRST
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DISABLE0
        • Disable direct reset by modem.
        ENABLE1
        • Enable direct reset by modem.
      • REALADC
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        COMPLEX0
        • ADC complex mode.
        REAL1
        • ADC real mode.

MODEM_AGC_CONTROL

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x35
  • Summary: Miscellaneous control bits for the Automatic Gain Control (AGC) function in the RX Chain.
  • Purpose:
    • This property provides several miscellaneous control bits for the AGC functionality. These control bits are primarily intended for engineering diagnostic purposes; Silicon Labs does not recommend altering the values suggested by the WDS Calculator, unless required to accommodate unusual customer applications.
  • Defaults: 0xe0
  • Register View:
    MODEM_AGC_CONTROL
    Index76543210
    0x35 AGCOVPKT IFPDSLOW RFPDSLOW SGI_N AGC_SLOW FORCE_ADC_GAIN_LOW ADC_GAIN_COR_EN RST_PKDT_PERIOD
    Defaults
    0x35 0x1 0x1 0x1 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_AGC_CONTROL
      • AGCOVPKT
        Description:
        • Selects whether the AGC operates over the entire packet, or only during acquisition of the Preamble.
        • Reductions in gain (in the event of signal level increases) are always allowed at any time, regardless of the state of this bit.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • The full AGC operates only during acquisition of the Preamble. Gain increases (in the event of a decrease in signal level) over the remainder of packet are not allowed.
        ENUM_11
        • AGC function operates over the entire packet.
      • IFPDSLOW
        Description:
        • The chip contains peak detectors in the IF chain for the purpose of sensing the signal level at the outputs of the IF PGAs. The information from these peak detectors is used by the AGC algorithm to adjust the gain of the RX chain (PGA and LNA).
        • In the event the signal level increases abruptly, it is desirable to decrease the gain rapidly else compression may occur in the RX chain. The IFPDSLOW bit controls the step size of gain reductions to the PGA, and thus affects the slope or speed of the AGC attack time.
        • This bit affects only the rate of gain decreases; increases in gain are always performed in 3 dB steps.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • The IF programmable gain loop will perform the first required gain decrease in a -3 dB step, but if further gain reductions are required (due to successive indications of the signal level exceeding the peak detector threshold) will switch to -6 dB steps.
        ENUM_11
        • The IF programmable gain loop will always perform gain decreases in -3 dB steps.
      • RFPDSLOW
        Description:
        • The chip contains RF peak detectors for the purpose of sensing the signal level at the output of the LNA. The information from these peak detectors is used by the AGC algorithm to adjust the gain of the RX chain (PGA and LNA).
        • In the event the signal level increases abruptly, it is desirable to decrease the gain rapidly else compression may occur in the RX chain. The RFPDSLOW bit controls the step size of gain reductions to the LNA, and thus affects the slope or speed of the AGC attack time.
        • This bit affects only the rate of gain decreases; increases in gain are always performed in 3 dB steps.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • The RF programmable gain loop will perform the first required gain decrease in a -3 dB step, but if further gain reductions are required (due to successive indications of the signal level exceeding the peak detector threshold) will switch to -6 dB steps.
        ENUM_11
        • The RF programmable gain loop will always perform gain decreases in -3 dB steps.
      • SGI_N
        Description:
        • Selects whether gain increases are allowed due to selection of a weak antenna during the Antenna Diversity algorithm.
        • This bit is effective only in ANT-DIV mode, and only during acquisition of the Preamble (when the signal strength of the two antennas is being evaluated).
        • This functionality is provided to prevent temporary overload of the RX Chain due to final selection of a strong antenna, after first adjusting the gain to a high value as a result of evaluation of a low signal on a weak antenna.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • AGC gain increases during signal reductions are prevented.
        ENUM_11
        • AGC gain increases during signal reductions are allowed.
      • AGC_SLOW
        Description:
        • The period of the AGC cycle (including both a measurement window period and a gain settling window period) is normally configured by the MODEM_AGC_WINDOW_SIZE property.
        • In the event that the AGC cycle speed cannot be configured to a sufficiently low value, the AGC speed may be reduced by an additional factor of 8x by setting the AGC_SLOW bit.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • Normal AGC speed.
        ENUM_11
        • AGC speed is reduced by a factor of 8.
      • FORCE_ADC_GAIN_LOW
        Description:
        • Forces the ADC input gain to be reduced by 6dB.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DO_NOTHING0
        • Does not modify the ADC GAIN.
        FORCE_LOW1
        • ADC input gain reduced by 6dB.
      • ADC_GAIN_COR_EN
        Description:
        • Selects whether the input gain of the RX A/D Converter is reduced when the condition of minimum AGC gain is detected.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ADC_GAIN_DIS0
        • Adjustment of the ADC input gain is disabled.
        ADC_GAIN_VIA_AGC1
        • ADC input gain is reduced by 6 dB, when the condition of minimum AGC gain is detected.
      • RST_PKDT_PERIOD
        Description:
        • Selects the period at which the IF and RF peak detectors are reset.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • The peak detectors are reset only when a change in gain is indicated by the peak detector output.
        ENUM_11
        • The peak detectors are reset on each and every cycle of the AGC algorithm.

MODEM_RESERVED_20_36

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x36
  • Summary: Reserved.
  • Purpose:
    • Reserved.
  • Defaults: 0x00
  • Register View:
    MODEM_RESERVED_20_36
    Index76543210
    0x36 RESERVED_20_36
    Defaults
    0x36 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_RESERVED_20_36
      • RESERVED_20_36
        Description:
        • reserved_20_36
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_RESERVED_20_37

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x37
  • Summary: Reserved.
  • Purpose:
    • Reserved.
  • Defaults: 0x00
  • Register View:
    MODEM_RESERVED_20_37
    Index76543210
    0x37 RESERVED_20_37
    Defaults
    0x37 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_RESERVED_20_37
      • RESERVED_20_37
        Description:
        • reserved_20_37
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_AGC_WINDOW_SIZE

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x38
  • Summary: Specifies the size of the measurement and settling windows for the AGC algorithm.
  • Purpose:
    • One cycle of the AGC algorithm consists of a measurement window period, a (potential) gain adjustment, and a gain settling window period.
    • During the measurement window period, the signal level is measured by peak detectors located at the outputs of the LNA and PGA gain stages. Gain adjustments (up or down) are performed depending upon whether the measured signal level falls within an amplitude threshold window.
    • The periods of both the measurement window and the gain settling window are adjustable. It is necessary that the measurement window is sufficient in length to allow capture of a peak of the sinusoidal IF signal. As the IF frequency used by the chip is configurable, the measurement window must also be configurable.
    • The units of the MEASWIN and SETTLEWIN fields are in periods of the oversampling clock for the Bit Clock Recovery (BCR) loop (e.g., typically 8 to 12 times the received data rate).
    • In the event that the window times obtained for the maximum values of MEASWIN and SETTLEWIN are not sufficiently long, their effective values may be simultaneously increased by a factor of 8x by setting the AGC_SLOW bit in the MODEM_AGC_CONTROL property. (This need is unlikely to occur.)
  • Defaults: 0x11
  • Register View:
    MODEM_AGC_WINDOW_SIZE
    Index76543210
    0x38 MEASWIN SETTLEWIN
    Defaults
    0x38 0x1 0x1

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_AGC_WINDOW_SIZE
      • MEASWIN
        Description:
        • Size of the signal level measurement window for the AGC algorithm.
        • Effective measurement time is:
          [LATEX equation: MEAS\_TIME = (\frac{MEASWIN \times 2^{3 \times AGCSLOW}}{F_{S BCR}})]
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x1
        Max:
        0xf
      • SETTLEWIN
        Description:
        • Size of the gain settling window for the AGC algorithm.
        • Effective settling time is:
          [LATEX equation: SETTLE\_TIME = (\frac{SETTLEWIN \times 2^{3 \times AGCSLOW}}{F_{S BCR}})]
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x1
        Max:
        0xf

MODEM_AGC_RFPD_DECAY

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x39
  • Summary: Sets the decay time of the RF peak detectors.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip contains RF peak detectors in the LNA for the purpose of sensing the signal level at the output of the LNA. The information from these peak detectors is used by the AGC algorithm to adjust the gain of the RX chain (PGA and LNA).
    • It is usually desirable for AGC circuitry to attack quickly (rapidly decrease the gain when the signal level increases) but decay slowly (slowly increase the gain when the signal level decreases).
    • To accomplish the slow decay, the chip requires that the peak detectors indicate a consecutive number of "signal below threshold" conditions before the gain is increased. The requirement for consistent indication for gain increase is advisable to prevent gain chattering. The required number of consecutive indications is set by the RFPD_DECAY value.
    • It is usually recommended to set the MODEM_AGC_IFPD_DECAY and MODEM_AGC_RFPD_DECAY properties to identical values.
  • Defaults: 0x10
  • Register View:
    MODEM_AGC_RFPD_DECAY
    Index76543210
    0x39 RFPD_DECAY
    Defaults
    0x39 0x10

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_AGC_RFPD_DECAY
      • RFPD_DECAY
        Description:
        • Specifies the consecutive number of AGC cycles for which the RF peak detectors must give a consistent increase gain indication, before the gain increase is allowed.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x1
        Max:
        0xff

MODEM_AGC_IFPD_DECAY

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x3a
  • Summary: Sets the decay time of the IF peak detectors.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip contains peak detectors in the IF chain for the purpose of sensing the signal level at the outputs of the IF PGAs. The information from these peak detectors is used by the AGC algorithm to adjust the gain of the RX chain (PGA and LNA).
    • It is usually desirable for AGC circuitry to attack quickly (rapidly decrease the gain when the signal level increases) but decay slowly (slowly increase the gain when the signal level decreases).
    • To accomplish the slow decay, the chip requires that the peak detectors indicate a consecutive number of "signal below threshold" conditions before the gain is increased. The requirement for consistent indication for gain increase is advisable to prevent gain chattering. The required number of consecutive indications is set by the IFPD_DECAY value.
    • It is usually recommended to set the MODEM_AGC_IFPD_DECAY and MODEM_AGC_RFPD_DECAY properties to identical values.
  • Defaults: 0x10
  • Register View:
    MODEM_AGC_IFPD_DECAY
    Index76543210
    0x3a IFPD_DECAY
    Defaults
    0x3a 0x10

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_AGC_IFPD_DECAY
      • IFPD_DECAY
        Description:
        • Specifies the consecutive number of AGC cycles for which the IF peak detectors must give a consistent increase gain indication, before the gain increase is allowed.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x1
        Max:
        0xff

MODEM_FSK4_GAIN1

  • Defaults: 0x0b

        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • Normal.
        ENUM_11
        • Disable 4(G)FSK ISI-suppression.
      • 4FSK_GAIN1
        Description:
        • Gain factor of the secondary branch in 4(G)FSK ISI-suppression.
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_FSK4_GAIN0

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x3c
  • Summary: Specifies the gain factor of the primary branch in 4(G)FSK ISI-suppression.
  • Purpose:
    • Controls 4(G)FSK suppression gain.
  • Defaults: 0x1c
  • Register View:
    MODEM_FSK4_GAIN0
    Index76543210
    0x3c PHASE_COMP_2FSK 4FSK_GAIN0
    Defaults
    0x3c 0x0 0x1c

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_FSK4_GAIN0
      • PHASE_COMP_2FSK
        Description:
        • If set, phase compensation is enabled.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DISABLED0
        • Disable phase compenstation for 2fsk..
        ENABLED1
        • Enable phase compenstation for 2fsk..
      • 4FSK_GAIN0
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_FSK4_TH

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x3d ... 0x3e
  • Summary: 16 bit 4(G)FSK slicer threshold.
  • Purpose:
    • 16 bit4(G)FSK slicer threshold.
  • Defaults: 0x40, 0x00
  • Register View:
    MODEM_FSK4_TH
    Index76543210
    0x3d 4FSKTH[15:8]
    0x3e 4FSKTH[7:0]
    Defaults
    0x3d 0x40
    0x3e 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_FSK4_TH
      • 4FSKTH
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_FSK4_MAP

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x3f
  • Summary: 4(G)FSK symbol mapping code.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip is capable of transmitting and receiving 4(G)FSK modulation. In this type of modulation, pairs of data bits are encoded/decoded into 1-of-4 possible frequency deviation levels. This property controls the mapping of bit pairs into deviation levels.
    • The four deviation levels are evenly spaced and symmetrical around the channel center frequency. As an example, the deviation levels for a 4(G)FSK modulation protocol with 10kHz spacing between levels would be: -15kHz, -5kHz, +5 kHz, and +15 kHz.
    • By convention, these four deviation levels are often referred to as the -3ΔF, -1ΔF, +1ΔF, and +3ΔF levels. This naming convention arises from the fact that the outer deviation (i.e., the difference between channel center frequency and the outer-most deviation levels) is always 3x the inner deviation.
    • There are 24 unique ways in which pairs of bits may be mapped to the four deviation levels. These methods are enumerated below. The coding of the enumerations is read (left to right) as: -3ΔF, -1ΔF, +1ΔF, and +3ΔF.
    • Using MODEM_FSK4_MAP = 0x00 as an example, the bit pair '00' would be mapped to the -3ΔF level, the bit pair '01' would be mapped to the -1ΔF level, the bit pair '11' to the +1ΔF level, and the '10' bit pair to the +3ΔF level.
    • It is important that the TX and RX sides of the link use the same 4(G)FSK symbol mapping, else establishment of the link may not be possible. Also, test equipment vendors may not all use the same default symbol mapping; settings that work with one piece of lab test equipment may not work with another.
  • Defaults: 0x00
  • Register View:
    MODEM_FSK4_MAP
    Index76543210
    0x3f 4FSKMAP
    Defaults
    0x3f 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_FSK4_MAP
      • 4FSKMAP
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • `00 `01 `11 `10
        ENUM_11
        • `00 `01 `10 `11
        ENUM_22
        • `00 `11 `01 `10
        ENUM_33
        • `00 `11 `10 `01
        ENUM_44
        • `00 `10 `01 `11
        ENUM_55
        • `00 `10 `11 `01
        ENUM_66
        • `01 `00 `11 `10
        ENUM_77
        • `01 `00 `10 `11
        ENUM_88
        • `01 `11 `00 `10
        ENUM_99
        • `01 `11 `10 `00
        ENUM_1010
        • `01 `10 `00 `11
        ENUM_1111
        • `01 `10 `11 `00
        ENUM_1212
        • `11 `00 `01 `10
        ENUM_1313
        • `11 `00 `10 `01
        ENUM_1414
        • `11 `01 `00 `10
        ENUM_1515
        • `11 `01 `10 `00
        ENUM_1616
        • `11 `10 `00 `01
        ENUM_1717
        • `11 `10 `01 `00
        ENUM_1818
        • `10 `00 `01 `11
        ENUM_1919
        • `10 `00 `11 `01
        ENUM_2020
        • `10 `01 `00 `11
        ENUM_2121
        • `10 `01 `11 `00
        ENUM_2222
        • `10 `11 `00 `01
        ENUM_2323
        • `10 `11 `01 `00

MODEM_OOK_PDTC

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x40
  • Summary: Configures the attack and decay times of the OOK Peak Detector.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip provides two different methods of developing the slicing reference level for demodulation of an OOK signal: Peak Detection, and a Moving Average Filter. This property configures the attack and decay times of the OOK peak detector.
    • The rate at which the peak detector charges or discharges is proportional to 2-ATTACK or 2-DECAY. As a result, larger values of the ATTACK and DECAY parameters result in slower attack and decay times, respectively.
    • Please refer to MODEM_OOK_MISC for more details regarding configuration of the detector(s) used in OOK demodulation.
  • Defaults: 0x2b
  • Register View:
    MODEM_OOK_PDTC
    Index76543210
    0x40 0 ATTACK DECAY
    Defaults
    0x40 0x0 0x2 0xb

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_OOK_PDTC
      • ATTACK
        Description:
        • Selection of the attack time of the OOK peak detector. The peak detector charges at a rate proportional to 2-ATTACK.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0x7
      • DECAY
        Description:
        • Selection of the decay time of the OOK peak detector. The peak detector discharges at a rate proportional to 2-DECAY.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0xf

MODEM_OOK_BLOPK

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x41
  • Summary: Configures the slicing reference level of the OOK Peak Detector.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip provides two different methods of developing the slicing reference level for demodulation of an OOK signal: Peak Detection, and a Moving Average Filter. This property configures the slicing reference level of the OOK peak detector.
    • The slicing reference level is defined as a selectable number of dB below the peak measured signal level.
  • Defaults: 0x0c
  • Register View:
    MODEM_OOK_BLOPK
    Index76543210
    0x41 BW_PK
    Defaults
    0x41 0xc

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_OOK_BLOPK
      • BW_PK
        Description:
        • Sets the slicing reference level of the OOK peak detector at a selectable number of dB below the peak measured level.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0xff

MODEM_OOK_CNT1

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x42
  • Summary: OOK control.
  • Purpose:
    • OOK control.
  • Defaults: 0xa4
  • Register View:
    MODEM_OOK_CNT1
    Index76543210
    0x42 S2P_MAP OOKFRZEN MA_FREQDWN RAW_SYN SLICER_FAST SQUELCH
    Defaults
    0x42 0x2 0x1 0x0 0x0 0x1 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_OOK_CNT1
      • S2P_MAP
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • S2p_mapping 0.
        ENUM_11
        • S2p_mapping 1.
        ENUM_22
        • S2p_mapping 2.
        ENUM_33
        • S2p_mapping 3.
      • OOKFRZEN
        Description:
        • This bit only has an effect after preamble is detected.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • Normal.
        ENUM_11
        • AGC and OOK moving average detector's threshold output will be frozen after the preamble is detected.
      • MA_FREQDWN
        Description:
        • If set, estimated frequency from MA detector will be trunked 4 bits to avoid overflow.
        • AFC gain should be increased 16 times if this bit is set.
        • It is recommended to set this bit for Rb smaller than 1kbps and/or hModInd greater than 50 if MA detector's frequency error estimator is selected.
        Type:
        U8
      • RAW_SYN
        Description:
        • If set, raw data output is synchronized to bit clock.
        Type:
        U8
      • SLICER_FAST
        Description:
        • This bit effects 2(G)FSK/OOK mode only.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • Discriminator's slicer output is de-glitched by bit clock.
        ENUM_11
        • Discriminator's slicer output is de-glitched by sample clock to reduce turn-around time.
      • SQUELCH
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • Squelch function is off.
        ENUM_11
        • When no signal is received, there is no toggling of RX data output.
        ENUM_22
        • When PM is not detected, there is no toggling of RX data output.
        ENUM_33
        • When no signal or PM is not detected, there is no toggling of RX data output.

MODEM_OOK_MISC

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x43
  • Summary: Selects the detector(s) used for demodulation of an OOK signal, or for demodulation of a (G)FSK signal when using the asynchronous demodulator.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip internally implements two different types of demodulator circuits: a synchronous demodulator and an asynchronous demodulator. The synchronous demodulator is typically used for reception of (G)FSK signals with a standard Preamble and packet structure, while the asynchronous demodulator is typically used for reception of (G)FSK signals with non-standard Preamble and packet structures, as well as for all OOK signals.
    • Within the asynchronous demodulator, several different types of detectors may be selected to establish the voltage reference level for slicing the received data bits.
    • This property is used to select among the following types of detectors: a moving average filter, a peak detector, and a min-max detector.
    • The moving average filter detector establishes the slicing threshold level based upon the average of the previous data bits, and thus works best when the data stream is balanced and contains numerous bit transitions (e.g., a Preamble pattern or Manchester-coded data). This type of detector may be used with both OOK and (G)FSK signals.
    • The peak detector establishes the slicing threshold level as a selectable number of dB below the peak measured signal level. This type of detector is applicable only for OOK signals.
    • The min-max detector establishes the slicing threshold level as the mid-point between the maximum and minimum detected frequency deviation levels. This type of detector is applicable only for (G)FSK signals.
  • Defaults: 0x03
  • Register View:
    MODEM_OOK_MISC
    Index76543210
    0x43 OOKFASTMA 0 OOK_LIMIT_DISCHG OOK_SQUELCH_EN OOK_DISCHG_DIV DETECTOR
    Defaults
    0x43 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x3

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_OOK_MISC
      • OOKFASTMA
        Description:
        • Selects whether the length of the moving average filter window (used to establish the slicing threshold value from the previous data bits) is as specified directly by the MODEM_RAW_SEARCH property, or the value in MODEM_RAW_SEARCH is effectively increased by 2x.
        • This bit is effective only when demodulating an OOK signal, and allows trading off accuracy of the slicing threshold with response time to the first bit(s) of the OOK packet.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        NORMAL_MA_WINDOW0
        • Normal.
        LONG_MA_WINDOW1
        • Deploy longer MA filter window.
      • OOK_LIMIT_DISCHG
        Description:
        • Configures if the peak detector discharge is limited.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ALWAYS_DISCHG0
        • Peak detector discharges always.
        LIMIT_DISCHG1
        • Peak detector discharge is disabled when the detected peak is lower than the input signal for low input levels.
      • OOK_SQUELCH_EN
        Description:
        • When set, squelches the RXDATA bit stream output in real-time on a selected GPIO pin until signal arrival is detected. This squelch functionality is only applicable when demodulating an OOK signal.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DISABLED0
        • Disable OOK Squelch functionality..
        ENABLED1
        • Enable OOK Squelch functionality..
      • OOK_DISCHG_DIV
        Description:
        • OOK Peak Detector discharge divider.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        NO_DISCHG_DIV0
        • Does not affect OOK decay rate specified in decay[3:0] in MODEM_OOK_PDTC .
        DISCHG_HALF1
        • OOK PK Detector discharges at half of the OOK decay rate specified in decay[3:0] in MODEM_OOK_PDTC .
        DISCHG_QUARTER2
        • OOK PK Detector discharges at a quarter of the OOK decay rate specified in decay[3:0] in MODEM_OOK_PDTC .
        DISCHG_EIGHTH3
        • OOK PK Detector discharges at an 8th of the decay rate specified in decay[3:0] in MODEM_OOK_PDTC .
      • DETECTOR
        Description:
        • Selects the type of detector used to establish the slicing threshold for asynchronous demodulation of the data.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        MA_PK0
        • Both the peak detector and the moving average filter detector are used; the outputs of the two detectors are logically AND'ed together to provide the final RX data stream. This option is applicable only when demodulating an OOK signal.
        PK1
        • PThe peak detector is selected to establish the slicing threshold level. Selection of the peak detector is only applicable when demodulating an OOK signal. The attack and decay times of the peak detector are controlled through the MODEM_OOK_PDTC property.
        MA2
        • The moving average filter detector is selected to establish the slicing threshold level. Selection of the MA filter detector is appropriate for demodulation of either an OOK signal or a (G)FSK signal with an unconventional (i.e., "legacy") packet structure. The MA filter window length is configured through the MODEM_RAW_SEARCH property.
        MEAN3
        • The min-max detector is selected to establish the slicing threshold level as the mid-point between the measured extreme frequency deviation levels. Selection of the min-max detector is applicable when demodulating a (G)FSK signal with an unconventional (i.e., "legacy") packet structure. The search window length (over which the min-max frequency values are measured) is configured through the MODEM_RAW_SEARCH property.

MODEM_RAW_SEARCH

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x44
  • Summary: Defines and controls the search period length for the Moving Average and Min-Max detectors.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip internally implements two different types of demodulator circuits: a synchronous demodulator and an asynchronous demodulator. The synchronous demodulator is typically used for reception of (G)FSK signals with a standard Preamble and packet structure, while the asynchronous demodulator is typically used for reception of (G)FSK signals with non-standard Preamble and packet structures, as well as for all OOK signals.
    • Within the asynchronous demodulator, several different types of detectors may be selected to establish the voltage reference level for slicing the received data bits, including a moving average filter, a peak detector, and a min-max detector. The type of detector used in the asynchronous demodulator is selected in the MODEM_OOK_MISC property. The moving average filter and min-max detectors both establish the slicing threshold level based upon the values of the previous data bits. This property is used to configure the number of previous data bits (i.e., search window length) over which the moving average and min-max detectors establish the slicing threshold level.
    • The search period length may be configured for different values before gear switching and after gear switching. A shorter search period window is typically selected prior to gear switching, as the Preamble field usually contains regular bit transitions and fast acquisition is desirable. A longer search period window is typically selected after gear switching, as the Payload fields may contain highly unbalanced data and irregular bit transitions; as a result, a longer search period may be required to capture both polarities of data bits for accurate establishment of the slicing threshold level.
    • Alternatively, the slicing threshold search engine may be "frozen" upon gear switching, such that no further adjustments to the slicing threshold level are made across the remainder of the packet.
  • Defaults: 0x56
  • Register View:
    MODEM_RAW_SEARCH
    Index76543210
    0x44 SCH_FRZEN SCH_FRZTH SCHPRD_HI SCHPRD_LOW
    Defaults
    0x44 0x0 0x5 0x1 0x2

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_RAW_SEARCH
      • SCH_FRZEN
        Description:
        • Selects whether the Moving Average or Min-Max slicing threshold search engine is frozen upon gear switching.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        DISABLED0
        • Do not freeze the Moving Average or Min-Max slicing threshold search engine upon switching to low gear.
        ENABLED1
        • Freeze the Moving Average or Min-Max slicing threshold search engine upon switching to low gear.
      • SCH_FRZTH
        Description:
        • This field only has an effect for a very specific chip configuration: a) The Asynchronous Demodulator is in use. b) The modulation type is not OOK. c)The Min-Max detector is used to develop the slicing threshold level (as configured in the MODEM_OOK_MISC property). d) Gear switching upon frequency settling is selected (as configured in the MODEM_AFC_GEAR property).
        • When configured in this fashion, the chip will gear switch when the estimated frequency error of the Min-Max detector remains within a window equal to 0.5*MODEM_RAW_EYE for a consecutive number of search periods.
        • The consecutive number of search periods is defined by SCH_FRZTH, while the length of each search period is defined by SCHPRD_HI.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x1
        Max:
        0x7
      • SCHPRD_HI
        Description:
        • Selects the search period window length (in bit periods) over which the Moving Average filter or Min-Max detector establishes the slicing threshold level, prior to gear switching (i.e., during high gear).
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        SEARCH_2TB0
        • Search window period = 2*TB
        SEARCH_4TB1
        • Search window period = 4*TB
        SEARCH_8TB2
        • Search window period = 8*TB
        SEARCH_16TB3
        • Search window period = 16*TB
      • SCHPRD_LOW
        Description:
        • Selects the search period window length (in bit periods) over which the Moving Average filter or Min-Max detector establishes the slicing threshold level, after gear switching (i.e., during low gear).
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        SEARCH_2TB0
        • Search window period = 2*TB
        SEARCH_4TB1
        • Search window period = 4*TB
        SEARCH_8TB2
        • Search window period = 8*TB
        SEARCH_16TB3
        • Search window period = 16*TB

MODEM_RAW_CONTROL

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x45
  • Summary: Defines gain and enable controls for raw / nonstandard mode.
  • Purpose:
    • Defines gain and enable controls for raw / nonstandard mode.
  • Defaults: 0x02
  • Register View:
    MODEM_RAW_CONTROL
    Index76543210
    0x45 UNSTDPK CONSCHK_BYP 0 0 PM_PATTERN RAWGAIN
    Defaults
    0x45 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x2

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_RAW_CONTROL
      • UNSTDPK
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • Standard packet mode.
        ENUM_11
        • MA or mean frequency error estimator.
      • CONSCHK_BYP
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • If unstdpk is '1', and conschk_byp= '0', the consecutive '1' or '0' of payload data during 'Sch_Period' will stop the mean value being updated.
        ENUM_11
        • Normal.
      • PM_PATTERN
        Description:
        • PM pattern configuration. The preamble detection is done inside modem.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        10100
        • If preamble has '1010' pattern, modem is recommended to work on standard packet mode.
        CONSECUTIVE_ONE1
        • If preamble has more than 32-bit consecutive '1' pattern, modem is recommended to work on un-standard packet mode.
        CONSECUTIVE_ZERO2
        • If preamble has more than 32-bit consecutive '0' pattern, modem is recommended work on un-standard packet mode.
        RANDOM3
        • If preamble is random data, modem is recommended to work on un-standard packet mode.
      • RAWGAIN
        Description:
        • Raw data MA filter gain.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • Gain = 8.
        ENUM_11
        • Gain = 4.
        ENUM_22
        • Gain = 2.
        ENUM_33
        • Gain = 1.

MODEM_RAW_EYE

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x46 ... 0x47
  • Summary: 11 bit eye-open detector threshold.
  • Purpose:
    • 11 bit eye-open detector threshold.
  • Defaults: 0x00, 0xa3
  • Register View:
    MODEM_RAW_EYE
    Index76543210
    0x46 0 0 0 0 0 RAWEYE[10:8]
    0x47 RAWEYE[7:0]
    Defaults
    0x46 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0
    0x47 0xa3

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_RAW_EYE
      • RAWEYE
        Description:
        • Eye-open detector threshold.
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_ANT_DIV_MODE

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x48
  • Summary: Antenna diversity mode settings.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip provides for automatic Antenna Diversity (AntDiv) functionality. During AntDiv operation, the signal strength on two spatially-separated antennas is evaluated and the stronger antenna is selected for reception over the remainder of the packet, thus improving link quality in the presence of fading due to multi-path propagation. This property configures various control bits for the AntDiv algorithm.
    • AntDiv functionality is only possible during reception of a packet with a Standard Preamble (i.e., 1010 or 0101 pattern).
    • Enabling the AntDiv algorithm creates the signals required for control of an external RF switch, but does not output them on GPIO pin(s). It remains necessary to additionally configure the appropriate GPIO pin(s) to output the ANTENNA_1_SW and ANTENNA_2_SW control signals.
    • As the stronger antenna is not known prior to the arrival of the packet, the AntDiv algorithm toggles between antennas with a period determined by the ANWAIT parameter. This toggling action continues until a PREAMBLE_VALID signal is detected on one of the antennas.
    • The RSSI level for that antenna is evaluated and stored in memory. The algorithm then briefly selects the alternate antenna and again evaluates the RSSI level. The two RSSI levels are compared and the chip selects the stronger antenna for the remainder of the packet.
    • As there may be some slight loss of bit synchronization during the antenna switching process, the chip qualifies the Preamble for a second time after selection of the good antenna. During this 2nd phase evaluation, the Preamble detection threshold is reduced to a smaller value as specified in the MODEM_ANT_DIV_CONTROL:ANT2PM_THD parameter.
    • If the signal strength on the 1st antenna is sufficiently strong, there is no need to evaluate the signal strength on the alternate antenna as no further improvement in link quality would be gained by selecting an even stronger signal. In such a case, the evaluation phase on the 2nd antenna may be skipped entirely, as controlled by the SKIP2PH and SKIP2PHTH parameters.
  • Defaults: 0x02
  • Register View:
    MODEM_ANT_DIV_MODE
    Index76543210
    0x48 SWANT_TIMER BYP1P5 SKIP2PH SKIP2PHTH ANWAIT
    Defaults
    0x48 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x2

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_ANT_DIV_MODE
      • SWANT_TIMER
        Description:
        • Selects the number of bit periods to wait for the RSSI value to stabilize during the 2nd phase antenna evaluation of the AntDiv algorithm.
        • Some amount of delay is necessary to allow the new signal level on the 2nd antenna to travel through the entire RX chain and to become stable (i.e., RX processing delay).
        • This field has no effect if not in AntDiv mode of operation.
        • The delay time (in bit periods) depends upon the amount of averaging performed on the RSSI signal (selected by the MODEM_ANT_DIV_CONTROL:MATAP bit) and is given by the following formulas:
          [LATEX equation: T = (SWANT\_TIMER \times 2) + 9 bit periods] (MATAP = 0)
          [LATEX equation: T = (SWANT\_TIMER \times 2) + 13 bit periods] (MATAP = 1)
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • 9 bit periods (MATAP = 0), 13 bit periods (MATAP = 1)
        ENUM_11
        • 11 bit periods (MATAP = 0), 15 bit periods (MATAP = 1)
        ENUM_22
        • 13 bit periods (MATAP = 0), 17 bit periods (MATAP = 1)
        ENUM_33
        • 15 bit periods (MATAP = 0), 19 bit periods (MATAP = 1)
      • BYP1P5
        Description:
        • Enables/disables a bias against the 2nd phase antenna evaluation.
        • By definition, a PREAMBLE_VALID signal was detected during the initial (1st phase) antenna evaluation, and indicates the signal strength on that antenna is likely sufficient to receive the packet. With this parameter, the chip may be configured to select the alternate antenna only if the 2nd phase antenna evaluation exceeds the signal strength on the 1st antenna by the selected amount of bias.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • Bias = 0 dB (2nd antenna will be selected if its signal strength exceeds the 1st antenna by any amount).
        ENUM_11
        • Bias = 1.5 dB (2nd antenna will be selected if its signal strength exceeds the 1st antenna by more than 1.5 dB).
      • SKIP2PH
        Description:
        • Enables skipping of the 2nd phase of antenna evaluation on packets where the relative signal strength of the 1st phase of antenna evaluation exceeds the threshold value selected in SKIP2PHTH, thus reducing packet acquisition time.
        • If the signal strength of the 1st phase of antenna evaluation does not exceed the threshold value, the AntDiv algorithm proceeds with the 2nd phase of antenna evaluation.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • The AntDiv algorithm always evaluates the signal strength on both antennas.
        ENUM_11
        • The AntDiv algorithm evaluates the signal strength on the initial antenna (i.e., the antenna on which a PREAMBLE_VALID signal is first detected), but skips evaluation of the alternate antenna when the relative signal strength (above background noise level) exceeds the threshold specified in SKIP2PHTH.
      • SKIP2PHTH
        Description:
        • Selects the signal strength threshold for determining when the 2nd phase of antenna evaluation may be skipped.
        • This threshold is not an absolute value, but is a relative value measured between the RSSI on the initial antenna (i.e., on which the 1st PREAMBLE_VALID indication was found) and the RSSI value on the previous antenna (presumably taken on noise prior to the arrival of the packet). As a result, this value serves as an approximate "dB above background noise level" threshold.
        • This parameter has no effect if the SKIP2PH bit is not also set.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • 16 dB threshold is set for skipping 2nd phase antenna detection.
        ENUM_11
        • 11 dB threshold is set for skipping 2nd phase antenna detection.
      • ANWAIT
        Description:
        • Configures the time period between toggling selection of antennas prior to arrival of the packet. (Periodic toggling is necessary during the initial search phase as the stronger antenna is not known prior to arrival of the packet.)
        • This field has no effect if not in AntDiv mode of operation.
        • The time period between antenna toggling is in increments of bit periods, and depends upon whether AFC is enabled in MODEM_AFC_GAIN:ENAFC according to the following formulas:
          [LATEX equation: T = (ANWAIT + 2) \times 4 + 3 bit periods] (AFC enabled)
          [LATEX equation: T = (ANWAIT + 2) \times 2 + 3 bit periods] (AFC disabled)
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0x7

MODEM_ANT_DIV_CONTROL

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x49
  • Summary: Specifies controls for the Antenna Diversity algorithm.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip provides for automatic Antenna Diversity (AntDiv) functionality. This property configures various control bits for the AntDiv algorithm.
    • Please refer to the text description for MODEM_ANT_DIV_MODE for more details regarding the Antenna Diversity functionality.
  • Defaults: 0x80
  • Register View:
    MODEM_ANT_DIV_CONTROL
    Index76543210
    0x49 ANT2PM_THD MATAP ANTDIV RESERVED
    Defaults
    0x49 0x8 0x0 0x0 0x0

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_ANT_DIV_CONTROL
      • ANT2PM_THD
        Description:
        • Some slight loss of bit synchronization may be introduced during the antenna switching process. As a result, it is necessary to re-acquire bit timing and re-qualify the Preamble after final selection of the best antenna.
        • During this re-qualification process, the Preamble detection threshold is reduced (from the value specified in the PREAMBLE_CONFIG_STD_1:RX_THRESH field) to the smaller value specified in the ANT2PM_THD parameter.
        • This field has no effect if not in AntDiv mode of operation.
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0xf
      • MATAP
        Description:
        • Configures the amount of averaging performed on the RSSI measurement by selecting the number of taps for a moving average.
        • Greater averaging allows for reduced noise variation on the measured RSSI value, but results in a longer required measurement time.
        • This bit has no effect if not in AntDiv mode of operation.
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        ENUM_00
        • Moving average filter tap length is 8*Tb prior to acquisition of the first PREAMBLE_VALID signal, and 4*Tb thereafter.
        ENUM_11
        • Moving average filter tap length is 8*Tb.
      • ANTDIV
        Description:
        • "Enables/disables operation of the AntDiv algorithm, resulting in generation of control signals appropriate for control of an antenna switch.
        • GPIO pin(s) must be additionally configured using GPIO_PIN_CFG to output the ANTENNA_1_SW and ANTENNA_2_SW control signals generated by the AntDiv algorithm.
        • The functionality of the ANTENNA_1_SW and ANTENNA_2_SW control signals also depends upon the operating mode of the chip (i.e., in RX mode, non-RX mode, or SLEEP mode).
        Type:
        Enumeration
        NameValueDescription
        RX_AUTO2
        • RX state: ANTENNA_1_SW and ANTENNA_2_SW = AntDiv algorithm
        • Non-RX state: ANTENNA_1_SW=1 and ANTENNA_2_SW = 0
        • SLEEP state: ANTENNA_1_SW=0 and ANTENNA_2_SW=0.
        FIXED0
        • RX state: ANTENNA_1_SW=1 and ANTENNA_2_SW=0
        • Non-RX state: ANTENNA_1_SW=1 and ANTENNA_2_SW = 0
        • SLEEP state: ANTENNA_1_SW=0 and ANTENNA_2_SW=0.
        FIXED_INV1
        • RX state: ANTENNA_1_SW=1 and ANTENNA_2_SW=0
        • Non-RX state: ANTENNA_1_SW=0 and ANTENNA_2_SW = 1
        • SLEEP state: ANTENNA_1_SW=0 and ANTENNA_2_SW=0.
        AUTO2
        • RX state: ANTENNA_1_SW and ANTENNA_2_SW = AntDiv algorithm
        • Non-RX state: ANTENNA_1_SW and ANTENNA_2_SW = Selected Antenna
        • SLEEP state: ANTENNA_1_SW=0 and ANTENNA_2_SW=0.
        AUTO_INV3
        • RX state: ANTENNA_1_SW and ANTENNA_2_SW = AntDiv algorithm
        • Non-RX state: ANTENNA_1_SW and ANTENNA_2_SW = Inverse of selected Antenna
        • SLEEP state: ANTENNA_1_SW=0 and ANTENNA_2_SW=0.
      • RESERVED
        Description:
        • Reserved bits (should always be written to 0).
        Type:
        U8

MODEM_RSSI_THRESH

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x4a
  • Summary: Configures the RSSI threshold.
  • Purpose:
    • Selects the threshold for Clear Channel Assessment (CCA) and generation of the RSSI interrupt.
    • If the Current RSSI value is above this threshold, a GPIO pin configured to output the CCA signal will be high.
    • If the Current RSSI value crosses above this threshold, the RSSI interrupt will be generated.
    • If enabled in the MODEM_RSSI_CONTROL property, the Latched RSSI value may also be compared against this threshold. The purpose of the comparison is to determine if the Latched RSSI value is below (not above) the threshold; if so, the chip proceeds to the specified START_RX:NEXT_STATE1:RXTIMEOUT_STATE and generates a PREAMBLE_INVALID interrupt.
  • Defaults: 0xff
  • Register View:
    MODEM_RSSI_THRESH
    Index76543210
    0x4a RSSI_THRESH
    Defaults
    0x4a 0xff

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_RSSI_THRESH
      • RSSI_THRESH
        Description:
        • Selects threshold for Clear Channel Assessment and generation of the RSSI interrupt (based upon comparison with the Current RSSI value).
        Type:
        U8
        Min:
        0x0
        Max:
        0xff

MODEM_RSSI_JUMP_THRESH

  • Group: 0x20
  • Index: 0x4b
  • Summary: Configures the RSSI Jump Detection threshold.
  • Purpose:
    • The chip provides the ability to detect a jump change in RSSI, and to take action as a result. Please refer to MODEM_RSSI_CONTROL2 for more details regarding configuration of RSSI Jump Detection functionality.
    • This property configures the threshold value for RSSI Jump Detection, in steps of 1dB. If the change in RSSI level (measured over a configurable amount of time) exceeds this threshold value, an RSSI Jump Detect interrupt event will be generated.
  • Defaults: 0x0c
  • Register View:
    MODEM_RSSI_JUMP_THRESH
    Index76543210
    0x4b 0 RSSIJMPTHD
    Defaults
    0x4b 0x0 0xc

  • Field Details:
    • MODEM_RSSI_JUMP_THRESH
      • RSSIJMPTHD
        Description:
